choices.text: Placing the cup on the fetal occiput and applying traction during maternal contractions
Placing the cup on the fetal occiput and applying continuous traction until delivery
Placing the cup on the fetal forehead and applying continuous traction until delivery
Placing the cup on the fetal forehead and applying traction during maternal contractions

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman at 39 weeks gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. She has been progressing well, but there is delayed progress in the 2nd stage of labor. The obstetrician decides to use vacuum extraction to assist with the delivery. The appropriate application of ventouse in this scenario involves:
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Placing the cup on the fetal occiput and applying traction during maternal contractions

Explanation

The vacuum cup is to be applied as close to the occiput as possible. This is the flexion point (3cm anterior to the posterior fontanellae) and traction on this point encourages flexion. Traction is applied during the contractions whilst encouraging the mother also to bear down. 

Other Options:

Option B: Placing the cup on the fetal occiput and applying continuous traction until delivery. This is incoorect as although placement is correct, traction is not continuois and only with uterine contractions

Option C: Placing the cup on the fetal forehead and applying continuous traction until delivery: This is incoorect as the cup placement has to be near the occiput. By placing the cup on the forehead, extension will happen which is not a favoured attitude. Also continuous traction is NOT applied. 

Option D: Placing the cup on the fetal forehead and applying traction during maternal contractions. This is incorrect as the cup placement has to be near the occiput. By placing the cup on the forehead, extension will happen which is not a favoured attitude

Educational Objective:

  • Application of Vacuum
    • Application of the cup
      • The cup is lubricated and introduced into the vagina
      • The center of the cup should be placed over the sagittal suture as close to the posterior fontanelle as possible (FLEXION POINT)
      • The Flexion point is a point 3 cm anterior to the post fontanellae
      • Traction at this point causes flexion of the head
    • Creation of the vacuum
      • First feel all around the cup to see that no maternal tissue is stuck in the cup
      • Cup is connected to the suction machine and vacuum till 0.8 kg/cm2 is created.
    • Traction
      • Traction is applied at right angles to the cup
      • Traction is applied intermittently with uterine contraction
      • Direction of traction: Along the pelvic curve (First downwards then horizontal then upwards)

 

Ref: Page no 1366, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Insertion of an intra-uterine device post-partum
Painting the parts prior to surgery
Removing retained products of conception
Removing the placenta following delivery

questions.text: What is the use of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Insertion of an intra-uterine device post-partum

Explanation

  • This is a Kelly’s forceps
  • It is a long forceps without a lock
  • It is used in post placental insertion of an intra-uterine device
  • Post placental IUCD insertion is done within 10 minutes of placental delivery

Other Options

  • Option A: Painting the parts prior to surgery: This is done by using a sponge holding forceps (aka ring forceps) and although very similar to a KElly;s forceps, has a lock and looks like as shown below

  • Option B: Removing retained products of conception: This is done by using an ovum forceps which is a long forceps without a lock but has an egg shaped end. It looks like: 

  • Option C: Removing the placenta following delivery: This si done manually, sometimes membranes need to be removed and this can be done using an artery forceps or a sponge holding forceps

Educational Objective:

  • This is a Kelly’s forceps
  • It is a long forceps without a lock
  • It is used in post placental insertion of an intra-uterine device
  • Post placental IUCD insertion is done within 10 minutes of placental delivery

 

ef:https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/familyplaning/schemes/24%20Standards%20for%20PPIUCD%20INSERTION%20FORCEPS.pdf

questions.text: What is the volume of the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 60ml

Explanation

This is a Manual Vacuum Aspirator and the volume of the cannula is 60ml

Educational Objective:

  • This is a Manual Vacuum Aspirator (MVA).
  • It consists of a large syringe which has a 60 ml cannula with a double valve system and a plunger
  • It is used in dilatation and evacuation procedures or suction and evacuation procedures in
    • Missed abortion
    • Incomplete abortion
    • Inevitable abortion
    • Surgical MTP till 12 weeks
    • Evacuation of molar pregnancy
  • After creating a vacuum manually, it is attached to the Karman cannula and the loaded apparatus is introduced into the uterus
  • The size of the Karman cannula is the POG in weeks
  • Using rotatory and back and forth movements, the products

 

 

Ref:https://www.ipas.org/resource/steps-for-performing-manual-vacuum-aspiration-using-the-ipas-mva-plus-and-easygrip-cannulae/

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman is in the second stage of labor. The obstetrician determines that an episiotomy is necessary to facilitate the delivery of the baby's head. When performing an episiotomy, which of the following instruments is commonly used?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Braun- Stadler scissors

Explanation

An episiotomy is given by a Braun-Stadler Episiotomy Scissors which looks like this:

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Scalpel: A scalpel is not used to give an episiotomy
  • Option B: Metzembaum scissors: This is a tissue cutting scissors and is used for dissection of tissue especialy fine and delicate structures. It looks like this:

  • Option D: Curved Mayo scissors is used to cut through tougher tissue structures like the uterus or muscle. It looks like this

Educational Objective:

 

An episiotomy is given by a Braun-Stadler Episiotomy Scissors which looks like this:

  • This is a scissors that is characteristically angulated in the middle and very easy to identify
  • The inside blade is guided by 2 fingers so as to avoid inadvertent injury to the fetus
  • Episiotomy should NOT be given routinely; rather restrictively in conditions like
    • Macrosomia
    • Assisted breech delivery
    • Use of instrumental delivery
    • Shoulder dystocia
    • Rigid perineum
  • The layers cut in an episiotomy from inside out are
    • Vaginal mucosa
    • Muscle (superficial and deep transverse perinei, Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani)
    • Perineal skin
  • An episiotomy is a type of 2nd degree perineal tear

Ref: Page 1306, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 32-year woman undergoes a lower segment cesareans section for obstructed labor. Following delivery of the baby, you note that the angles of the incision are bleeding profusely. The following instrument is best used to catch the bleeding angles:
questions.solution:
Ans: A. A

Explanation

  • The preferred forceps in this scenario is the Green Armytage forceps which is as shown below.

 

  • This is used to hold the angles and edges of the cesarean scar if there is excessive bleeding. Normally the edges are held with an allis forceps but in case of heavy bleeding, a Green Armytage forceps is better as it is less traumatic and has a wider surface area.
  • Usually, the angles of the incision are held with an Allis forceps but in the given scenario, a Green Armytage wd be better

Other Options: 

  • Option B: : This is an allis forceps. It is usually used to hold tough structures including the angles and edges of a cesarean section uterine incision but in the event of a large bleeded, a green armytage is preferred
  • Option C: : This is an artery forceps and is used to catch and grasp a bleeding vessel but usually this isn;'e useful in large uterine vessels seen at the angles of the uterine incision
  • Option D: : This is a babcocks forceps which is used to hold delicate structures like the fallopian tube and the appendix

Educational Objective:

  • This is a Green Armytage Forceps
  • This is used to hold the angles and edges of the cesarean scar if there is excessive bleeding. Normally the edges are held with an allis forceps but in case of heavy bleeding, a Green Armytage forceps is better as it is less traumatic and has a wider surface area

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics

choices.text: Delivering the baby
Delivering the placenta
Avoiding injury to the bowel
Keeping the bladder away from the uterine incision

questions.text: The following instrument helps in which important step during a cesarean?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Keeping the bladder away from the uterine incision

Explanation

This is a Doyen’s Retractor: This is a specially shaped retractor that keeps the bladder away from the uterine incision (lower segment cesarean section) thereby preventing bladder injury

Educational Objective: 

This is a Doyen’s Retractor: This is a specially shaped retractor that keeps the bladder away from the uterine incision (lower segment cesarean section) thereby preventing bladder injury

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics

choices.text: It is used to remove retained products of conception
It does not have a lock to enable a faster procedure time
It can be used in places where a vacuum aspirator is not available
The end is “egg-shaped” to collect and remove tissue

questions.text: Which is INCORRECT regarding the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. It does not have a lock to enable a faster procedure time

Explanation

Let's discuss all the options: 

  • Option A: It is used to remove retained products of conception: This is correct. An ovum forceps is used to remove retained products of conception in incomplete and missed abortions and also in surgical MTP
  • Option B: It does not have a lock to enable a faster procedure time: This is incorrect. The reasonf ro not having a lock is to avoid inadvertent injury to the uterus
  • Option C: It can be used in places where a vacuum aspirator is not available: This is correct. Evacuation of products can be done either by a manual or electrical vacuum aspirator or by an ovum forceps
  • Option D: The end is “egg-shaped” to collect and remove tissue: This is also correct. The end is egg shaped; hence the name ovum. The reason for this is to collect tissue within the endometrial cavity.

Educational Forceps:

  • This is an Ovum forceps
  • It is a long instrument used to evacuate products of conception in
    • Missed abortion
    • Incomplete abortion
    • Inevitable abortion
    • Surgical MTP till 12 weeks
    • Evacuation of molar pregnancy
  • Imp features of this instrument
    • End is oval or egg shaped
    • There is no lock; this is to prevent inadvertent injury to the uterus in case uterine tissue gets caught in the jaws

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is undergoing a cesarean section for previous 2 cesareans. She requests tubal ligation to be done also. Which of the following instruments will you ask the OT assistant to keep ready along with the cesarean instrument set?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Babcock forceps

Explanation

  • As the tubal ligation will be done along with the cesarean section, a Pomeroy’s ligation will be done and hence Babcock forceps is used

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Falope ring: This is an inert, radio-opaque silicone band that is applied to a looped section of the fallopian tube with a laprosator
  • Option B: Laparoscator is the laparoscopic instrument used to apply the falope ring
  • Option D: Filshie clip: This is a silicone lined titanium occlusive device used to  clip the fallopian tubes in laparoscopic tubal ligation

Educational Objective:

This is a Babcocks forceps. It is used to hold delicate structures like the fallopian tube. This is how it looks like: 

 

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics

questions.text: A woman is undergoing a salpingectomy for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. The fallopian tube is held with which instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Babcock forceps

Explanation

  • The Babcok forceps is used to hold delicate structures like the fallopian tubes
  • Used in tubal sterilization procedures like Pomeroy technique and also in tubal recanalization procedures

Educational Objective:

This is a Babcocks forceps. It is used to hold delicate structures like the fallopian tube. This is how it looks like: 

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics

questions.text: A 23-year primi presents with watery vaginal discharge which wet her clothes at 32 weeks pregnancy. There is no abdominal pain and she appreciates fetal movements well. Abdominal exam reveals a 32 weeks uterus with a live fetus in cephalic presentation. Which instrument will you use to confirm if the patient has ruptured her membranes?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Sim’s Speculum

Explanation

  • Preterm Prelabor Rupture of Membranes (PPROM) presents as sudden vaginal watery discharge
  • To confirm PPROM or PROM, a speculum exam is done
  • Ideally, a Sim’s speculum is inserted into the vagina and pooling of liquor on the blade of the speculum confirms the diagnosis

Other Options:

  • Option A: Cuscos speculum: This can be used to look for vaginal leaking but the preferred instrument is the Sims speculum as pooling of fluid can be seen in the central groove of the speculum
  • Option C: Fetoscope: This is used to auscultate the fetal heart rate
  • Option D: Hysteroscope: This is a scope to look inside the uterine cavity and is used for diagnostic procedures like AUB and operative procedures like Ashermam syndrome or hysteroscopic polypectomy. It is contra-indicated in pregnancy

Educational Objective: 

A Sims speculum is the preferred instrument used to look for pooling of liquor in a patient with suspected PROM or PPROM

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics

choices.text: A grating sensation on the anterior uterine wall
A grating sensation on the posterior uterine wall
A grating sensation on the lateral uterine walls
A grating sensation on all 4 uterine walls

questions.text: A woman is undergoing a surgical procedure to remove products of conception following an incomplete abortion. The following instrument is used. What sign will tell you that the procedure is complete?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. A grating sensation on all 4 uterine walls

Explanation

  • This is an instrument which is used to curette the endometrium
  • It is used following a suction evacuation after suctioning out the products or after removing them with an ovum forceps to ensure everything has been removed
  • It is also used in gyn procedures like a dilatation and curettage to get an endometrial biopsy
  • It has 2 ends
    • Blunt: used in obstetric procedures
    • Sharp: Used in gyn procedures
  • Procedure is complete if
    • Grating on all 4 walls
    • Presence of air bubbles
    • No bleeding

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics
